description: Learn to style specific states of an element (like hover) and insert content using CSS pseudo-elements.

slides.title: What are Pseudo-classes?
slides.content:
# Pseudo-classes üëª

A pseudo-class is used to define a special state of an element.

Used to:
- Style an element when a user mouses over it.
- Style visited and unvisited links differently.
- Style an element when it gets focus.

Syntax: `selector:pseudo-class { ... }`

slides.title: Interaction States
Structural Pseudo-classes
Link States
slides.content:
# Link States üîó

The 4 states of a link (order matters: LVHA):

1.  `a:link` (unvisited)
2.  `a:visited`
3.  `a:hover`
4.  `a:active`

```css
a:visited {
  color: purple;
}
```

slides.title: Pseudo-elements
slides.content:
# Pseudo-elements üß©

A pseudo-element is used to style specified parts of an element.

- `::first-line`: Style the first line of a text.
- `::first-letter`: Style the first letter.
- `::before`: Insert content before.
- `::after`: Insert content after.

Syntax: `selector::pseudo-element { ... }` (double colon is the modern standard).

slides.content:
# Recap: Pseudo-Classes üéì

State and structure.

- **Classes (`:`):** `:hover`, `:active`, `:focus`, `:first-child`, `:nth-child`.
- **Elements (`::`):** `::before`, `::after` (require `content`), `::first-line`.
- **Power:** Create complex interactions and visuals without changing HTML.
